title: Feline herpesvirus type 1 (FHV-1)
detail:
• Causes viral tracheitis; upper respiratory infection including sneezing, discharge, and fever
• Highly contagious; spread through direct contact—can survive 24 hours in the environment
• Cats previously infected can experience disease symptoms (including shedding) after a stressful experience (i.e. latent infection)

title: Feline calicivirus (FCV)
detail:
• One of the most common feline upper respiratory infection and oral ulceration
• More than 40 strains of calicivirus w different severity
• Virus shed by oral, nasal, conjunctival secretion, and through urine and feces, for up to 21 days
• Virus can survive in the environment for a week
• Clinical signs include ulcers on the tongue, gums, hard palate, nose, and lips
• Many develop a carrier state after recovery for months or even a lifetime

title: Congestive heart failure
detail:
• Occurs when heart disease causes poor cardiac output, which leads to poor venous return to the heart
• Left-sided CHF leads to pulmonary edema, dyspnea, tachypnea, abnormal respiratory sounds, cough
• Right-sided CHF leads to edema in the thoracic and abdominal cavities and jugular

title: Sinus bradycardia
detail:
• Slow but regular ventricular heart rate (less than 70 bpm for dogs under 20 kg; 60 bpm for dogs above 20 kg; 100 bpm for all cats)
• Can lead to weakness, hypotension, syncope (fainting due to hypotension), excessive or reduced parasympathetic tone, struggling to draw in air, gastric irritation, increased cerebrospinal fluid pressure, hypothyroidism, hypothermia, hyperkalemia, hypoglycemia

title: Respiratory sinus arrhythmia
detail:
• Sinus refers to the sinoatrial/sinus node
• Normal variation in heartbeat as influenced by respiratory patterns
• Typically, heart rate increases during respiration and decreases during inspiration (more pronounced in young animals)
• Respiratory disease or neurologically induced cardiac variations (including emotions) can change this

title: Heartworm disease
detail:
• Spread by mosquitos
• Both dogs and cats
• Cats present w coughing, vomiting, lethargy, anorexia and weight loss, dyspnea; dogs present w coughing, right-sided CHF, syncope, exercise intolerance, dyspnea, hemoptysis (coughing up blood)
• No treatment for cats, risky treatment for dogs; hemoptysis, dyspnea, and coughing are signs of pulmonary thromboembolism that can occur with adulticide treatment of heartworm
• Prevention is key—ivermectin, moxidectin, milbemycin oxime, selamectin
• Ivermectin (Heartgard) is a monthly antiparasitic
• Pyrantel pamoate (Heartgard plus) will also kill roundworms and hookworms
• Milbemycin oxime is a monthly antiparasitic that will also kill roundworms, hookworms, and whipworms
• Selamectin (Revolution) is a monthly topical antiparasitic that kills HW infective larvae, fleas, hookworms, roundworms, and ear mites
• Moxidectin is an antiparasitic that kills HW infective larvae and hookworms (monthly topical or 6-month SQ injectable versions)

title: Pancreatitis
detail:
• Inflammation of the pancreas, which produces digestive enzymes and regulatory hormones like glucagon
• Occurs when trypsin (a protease, a type of enzyme that breaks down proteins) is activated early in the pancreas, instead of its regular site duodenum, causing damage
• More commonly acute in dogs and chronic in cats
• Predisposing/contributing factors are a high-fat diet, genetics, abrupt dietary changes, trauma, drug toxicity, hormonal disease
• Acute (caused by dietary indiscretion) signs include anorexia, fever, vomiting, diarrhea, and later hypotension, renal failure, disseminated intravascular coagulation, multiple organ failure
• Chronic (cause unknown) signs include anorexia, lethargy, weight loss, hiding, can lead to diabetes mellitus and exocrine pancreatic insufficiency
• Treatment w hydration therapy and pain management

title: Canine parvoviral enteritis (PVE)
detail:
• Canine parvovirus (CPV) is highly contagious; spreads directly via fecal-oral route and indirectly via fomites (objects or materials which are likely to carry infection, such as clothes)
• Resistant to many disinfectants, can survive even years
• Shedding occurs days after infection, often before signs, and can continue 10 days after recovery
• Signs are acute and include vomiting, diarrhea (often hemorrhagic), dehydration, nausea, anorexia, depression, lethargy, abdominal pain, fever, leukopenia, neurological signs
• Diagnosed via fecal antigen testing
• Treatment is supportive—hydration therapy, antiemetics, antibiotics, nutritional support
• Spread prevented via isolation, PPE + diluted foot bath, cleaning w bleach or hydrogen peroxide
• Vaccines administered at 8 weeks, 12 weeks, 16 weeks, boostered first a year later, than every 3 years

title: Feline panleukopenia (FPV)
detail:
• Aka feline distemper of parvovirus (FPV)
• Highly contagious, often fatal for kittens; kills dividing cells of bone marrows, intestines, lymph nodes
• Can persist in environment for a year
• Shed by feces, urine, blood, secretions for 6 weeks after recovery; spread by vertical transmission, direct oronasal infection (including breastmilk), and indirect infection via fomites
• Treatment is supportive—hydration therapy, antiemetics, antimicrobials, nutritional support, sometimes immunotherapy

title: Chronic kidney disease
detail:
• Irreversible, progressive loss of renal function due to tissue damage, mostly due to another primary disease
• Glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is an estimate of the glomerulus’ filtration function
• Most common in geriatric animals
• Symptoms may include azotemia, hypertension, proteinuria, PU/PD, V/D, lethargy, anorexia, dehydration, oral ulceration, anemia
• Classified into 4 stages:
• 1—subclinical, usually undetected
• 2—GFR<25% of normal, azotemia w decreased ability to concentrate urine leading to PU/PD
• 3—GFR decline, azotemia and clinical signs present, reevaluation needed every 3-6 mo
• 4-- GFR decline, severe azotemia and clinical signs present, reevaluation needed every 1-3 mo
• Treatment involves identifying and treating primary disease, slowing progression of disease, correcting electrolyte imbalances

title: Acute kidney injury (acute renal failure)
detail:
• Can be caused by toxins, ischemia (inadequate blood supply), infection
• Clinical signs include V/D, anorexia, depression, oliguria, oral ulceration
• Graded I-V based on creatinine level (less than 1.6 mg/dL to more than 10 mg/dL)
• Serious, 50% survival rate
• Treated w hydration therapy, attempts to increase urine output
• Dialysis may be necessary

title: Urolithiasis
detail:
• Urolith (calculus) is a mineral-salt stone in the urinary tract
• Named based on location—nephrolith is in the nephron, urocystolith is in the bladder, ureterolith is in the ureter
• May cause vomiting, abdominal pain, depression, anorexia, stranguria, polyuria
• Treatment includes surgical or catheter removal of stones, lithotripsy (use of shock waves to break them), dissolution via urinary acidification
• Can be prevented by dietary changes

title: UTI
detail:
• Can be secondary to diseases like diabetes mellitus, hyperadrenocorticism, chronic kidney disease, infection
• Can present w dysuria, hematuria, polyuria
• Samples can contain RBCs, WBCs, bacteria (most commonly E. coli)
• Treated w anitbiotics

title: Feline lower urinary tract disease (FLUTD) (feline urologic syndrome)
detail:
• Lower urinary tract consists of the bladder, ureters, urethra
• Common signs are polyuria, hematuria, stranguria; may be caused by urolithiasis, neoplasia, trauma, feline interstitial or idiopathic cystitis, UTI
• Mostly in cats 2-6 years old
• Obstructive FLUTD (urethra obstruction) is an emergency; most common in male cats

title: Hyperthyroidism
detail:
• Occurs when the thyroid gland is overactive and produces too much thyroxine (T4) and triiodothyronine (T3), leading to increased metabolic rate
• Thyroid gland is wrapped around the front of the trachea, below the larynx
• Most common in middle-aged and geriatric cats; uncommon in other species
• Signs include weight loss, increased appetite, increased excitability or activity, PU/PD, V/D
• Elevated T4 serum levels, tachycardia, heart murmur, hypertension, enlarged thyroid gland or tumor, dyspnea, CHF possible
• Treatment includes thyroidectomy, radioactive iodine medication, antithyroid drugs, and low-iodine diet

title: Hypothyroidism
detail:
• Occurs due to deficiency of thyroid hormones leading to decreased metabolic rate
• Most common in dogs, usually resulting from damage to thyroid gland caused by:
• Lymphocytic thyroiditis (immune-mediated destruction of thyroid gland)
• Idiopathic thyroid atrophy (spontaneous replacement of thyroid tissue w adipose tissue w/out known cause)
• Affects the whole body since thyroid hormone affects all, resulting in nonspecific clinical signs that relate to metabolism slowing; lethargy, depression, dullness, exercise intolerance, weight gain w/out appetite increase, low T3-T4 serum levels, nonpruritic alopecia, hypothermia, heat-seeking behavior
• Treated w daily oral hormone replacement drugs (supplemental thyroid, most commonly T4 (thyroxine)

title: Diabetes mellitus (DM)
detail:
• Insulin deficiency
• Type-1 (insulin dependent) DM: Insufficient insulin production; more common in middle-aged dogs, no remission possible
• Type-2 (non-insulin dependent) DM: Endogenous insulin resistance; more common in cats
• Signs include polyphagia (excessive eating), weight loss, PU/PD
• Diagnosis confirmed w presence of hyperglycemia and glycosuria (check fructosamine levels in cats to rule out stress-induced hyperglycemia, which is common)

title: Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA)
detail:
• Occurs when DM goes untreated—body uses an alternative carbohydrate metabolism pathway due to prolonged insulin deficiency, which produces toxic ketones
• Ketones are molecules produced by the body when it burns fat for energy instead of sugar
• Ketones will be excreted in the urine (ketonuria) and may cause a fruity smell in the breath
• Usually presents as an emergency w history of anorexia, PU/PD, vomiting, weight loss, hypo- or hyperthermia, neurological signs, abdominal pain
• Treated by responding to dehydration, metabolic acidosis, decreased serum potassium, phosphorus, sodium levels

title: Hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing)
detail:
• Elevated cortisol levels; hard to diagnose, progressive
• Signs include PU/PD, increased appetite and weight gain, lethargy, alopecia, muscle atrophy, enlarged pot-belly abdomen, secondary UTIs
• Most cases occur due to pituitary-dependent hyperadrenocorticism, which is caused by and ACTH-secreting pituitary tumor (mostly in dogs, rare in cats); treated by treating symptoms of hypercortisolemia
• Adrenal-dependent version is much less common and caused by adrenal tumors; treated by removing tumors

title: Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison’s)
detail:
• Deficiency in adrenal hormones, especially cortisol and aldosterone
• Most commonly in dogs, sometimes in horses
• Signs include anorexia, V/D, PU/PD, weight loss, bradycardia, weakness, collapse, anemia, hypoglycemia, hyperkalemia, hyponatremia

title: IMHA
detail:
• Most common cause of hemolytic anemia
• Hemolysis: Rupturing of RBCs
• Idiopathic in dogs—immune system develops antibodies that react w self-antigens of RBCs w no known cause; secondary to a blood parasite in cats
• 20-75% mortality rate
• Signs include lethargy, exercise intolerance, icterus (jaundice), tachycardia, heart murmur, splenomegaly, hepatomegaly
• Pulmonary embolism is a risk in dogs
• Diagnosed by checking for evidence of autoimmune disease, like autoagglutination (i.e. clumping of erythrocytes due to antibodies)
• Treated w immunosuppressants, blood transfusions, hydration therapy, anticoagulants
• Omega-3 fatty acids have a significant effect on survival times (also for chronic valvular disease) attributed to anti-inflammatory effects, cachexia prevention, improved appetite, or antiarrhythmic effects

title: Myasthenia gravis (MG)
detail:
• Neuromuscular disease; causes generalized muscle weakness
• Can be congenital or acquired—congenital if there is an inherited deficiency in the acetylcholine (NT) receptors of the post-synaptic membrane, acquired if immune-mediated (antibodies against the receptors)
• IV edrophonium quickly resolves exercise-induced stiffness
• Diagnosed by presence of serum ACH-receptor autoantibodies
• Treated w anticholinesterase (against the enzyme that breaks down ACH) and immunosuppressants

title: Tick-borne diseases
detail:
• Anaplasmosis: Joint pain leading to lameness, fever, V/D; in cats and dogs
• Ehrlichiosis: Depression, anorexia, fever, joint pain, bruising; in cats and dogs
• Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever: Anorexia, joint pain, fever, V/D, pneumonia, kidney and liver failure, neurological signs; in cats and dogs, if attached 5+ hours
• Lyme disease: Fever, swollen lymph nodes, anorexia, and in more severe cases kidney and heart disease
• Common treatment is antibiotics, plus vaccine for dogs against Lyme

title: Feline Leukemia Virus (FeLV)
detail:
• Retrovirus—invades cells and inserts a copy of genetic material with the help of the reverse transcriptase enzyme
• Spread through saliva, nasal secretions, feces, urine, and nursing
• Outdoor cats more at risk, but exposure doesn’t mean infection (virus may or may not replicate)
• FeLV-A affects all infected cats, causes severe immunosuppression, is easily transmitted
• FeLV-B occurs in half of the infected cats, causes neoplastic disease
• FeLV-C affects less than 1% of infected cats, causes severe anemia
• No treatment, so vaccination is crucial

title: Leptospirosis
detail:
• Caused by the Leptospira bacteria found in water and soil
• Spread by drinking contaminated water or smelling wildlife urine (open wound coming in contact), eating or getting bit by infected animal
• Transmitted through the placenta to puppies as well
• Zoonotic—can cause flu symptoms and kidney/liver disease in humans
• Common in dogs, rare in cats
• Signs include fever, lethargy, V/D, abdominal pain, muscle soreness, increased thirst and urination
• Treated w antibiotics (primarily doxycycline) and intensive supportive care (IV fluids, pain meds, nutritional support)

title: Tetanus
detail:
• Caused by the Clostridium tetani bacteria found in soil; neurotoxins created by the bacteria affect the nervous system
• Typically enters body through puncture wound
• Highly fatal neurologic disease characterized by a stiff, stilted gait, hyperexcitability, seizure, and coma
• Other signs include stiffness (sawhorse stance), decrease in water and food consumption, hypersensitivity to noise and light, muscle fasciculations
• Treatment includes cleansing of wound site, topical penicillin along w IV penicillin and other fluids
• Dogs and cats not susceptible; annual vaccine recommended for dogs

title: Ringworm (dermatophytosis)
detail:
• Fungal disease that infects the skin, hair, and claws
• Caused by Microsporum canis (mostly), M. gypseum, or Trichophyton mentagrophytes in dogs
• Signs include alopecia, crusts, bumps, mainly on face, ears, tail, and feet
• Zoonotic, spread easily by contact w contaminated animals or objects
• Some can be asymptomatic carriers

title: Ctenocephalides felis
detail:
• Common cat flea
• Fleas lay eggs in the fur, eggs fall on the carpet/dirt where they hatch, flea larvae feed on organic debris in the environment and feces of adult fleas, mature larvae produce a cocoon, and emerge when stimulated by pressure or heat (can remain in cocoon up to a year), begin feeding immediately once on a host

title: Neoplastic diseases
detail:
• Encapsulated tumors are easier to remove than diffuse (fuzzy, tentacle-like) tumors
• Malignant tumors should be removed w 1-2 inches of healthy issue bordering the tumor
• Cryosurgery is done by freezing external epithelial lesions with liquid nitrogen and removing dead cancerous tissue
• Chemotherapy applies cytotoxic agents to cancerous regions; best for systemic and metastatic cancers
• Radiotherapy applies ionizing radiation, interrupting the cell’s DNA replication and resulting in its death
• Cauterization burns away epithelial tumors

title: Sarcoma
detail:
• Sarc/flesh + oma/tumor
• -oma is used for both benign and malignant
• Malignancy that grows in muscle, tendon, bone, fat, cartilage, and other soft tissue
• Originates in mesenchymal connective tissue or embryonic mesodermal tissue found in muscle, bone, fat, cartilage

title: Melanoma
detail:
• Malignant tumor; may or may not be accompanied by dark pigmentation
• Most common sites are skin, digits, and mouth
• More common in dogs, especially aged 9-12
• Prone to metastasizing through the lymphatic system to nodes or the blood system
• Responds best to early treatments

title: Squamous cell carcinoma
detail:
• Most common type of malignant tumor that can develop in the epithelial layer of the skin; can also develop in mucous membranes; attacks adjacent tissue and spreads to destroy bones
• Mostly in cats, can also occur in dogs
• Tumor is grayish white or pink, abnormally shaped; ulceration is common
• Mostly in gingiva, tonsils, nose
• Aggressive but treatable w surgery, radiation, hyprethermia

title: Epulis
detail:
• Non-malignant cancer
• Begins in the periodontal ligament and attacks adjacent tissue to spread to bone
• Fibromatous epulides (from tissue fiber), ossifying epulides (from bine cells and fibrous tissue; can develop into cancer), and acanthomatous epulides (grow into bone)

title: Obesity
detail:
• More than 20% in excess of ideal body weight is considered obese
• Obese cats more prone to diabetes because extra fat leads to insulin resistance, and to hepatic lipidosis if cat becomes stress and stops eating, leading to metabolizing fat
• All pets can get arthritis due to excess weight on joints
• Brachycephalic breeds are prone to troubled breathing because lungs can’t inflate properly due to extra fat

title: Osteoarthritis
detail:
• Results when cartilage in the joints degenerates, causing pain and inflammation
• Can be caused by infection, trauma, degenerative joint disease
• Obesity is a risk factor
• Most common traumatic cause in dogs is ruptured cruciate ligaments, risk of which increases w obesity
• Signs include lameness, muscle wasting, inability to get up and down stairs, jump, get up after laying down
• Radiographs may show soft-tissue swelling around the joint, increased joint fluid, and narrower joint space
+ Osteomalacia is softening of bones; osteopetrosis is hardening of bones

title: Endotoxemia
detail:
• Endotoxin is a cell-wall component of gram-negative bacteria, which can enter the bloodstream and cause illness
• Horses are very sensitive, require aggressive treatment including surgical excision of compromised intestine
• Can occur secondary to enterocolitis when GI microbiome is altered and bacteria proliferate, or due to retained placenta, uterine infection (metritis), pneumonia, peritonitis, or large wounds
• Signs include fever, tachycardia, hyperemic mucous membranes, leukopenia, laminitis, depression

title: Colic (Horses)
detail:
• Number 1 cause of premature equine fatality
• Caused by poor feed quality or feeding/hydration patterns, intestinal tears/torsions/hernias, disproportionate gas, sporadic cramps, ileus (GI atony), parasitic infections, volvulus (bowel obstruction from intestinal torsion), intussusception, obstructions, displacement, inguinal hernias, ulcers
• Treated w fluids, anti-inflammatory drugs, mineral oil, antiflatulence drugs, antiulcer drugs, corrective surgery

title: Colitis (Horses)
detail:
• Not clear, but may be due to dietary changes, excessive carbohydrate consumption, Potomac horse fever, antibiotics, overuse of NSAIDs
• Acute colitis signs include inappetence, listlessness, depression, abdominal pain, hyper- or hypomotility, increased HR and RR, discolored mucous membranes, increased CRT, diarrhea, dehydration, hypoproteinemia, electrolyte imbalance metabolic acidosis, and shock (mostly due to endotoxemia)
• Treated w fluids (balanced electrolyte solution), possibly a vasodilator like nitroglycerin

title: Salmonellosis (Horses)
detail:
• Number 1 cause of infectious diarrhea in horses
• Extremely contagious and zoonotic
• Profuse, watery, foul-smelling diarrhea
• May be accompanied by fever and anorexia
• Isolation necessary
• Treated w fluids (electrolytes), possible plasma transfusion if hypoproteinemia present
• Grain should not be part of the diet
• Colitis X is a possibly deadly form of the disease, treated w oral antibiotics

title: Anterior enteritis (Horses)
detail:
• Can be linked to Clostridium spp, but thought as idiopathic
• Signs include severe colic, high HR/RR, possibly fever
• Horses can’t vomit, so nasogastric tube is necessary for treatment to remove fluids and avoid rupture
• Fluid therapy necessary as well (jugular vein, 60-100 L per day as replacement)

title: Potomac horse fever (Monocytic ehrlichiosis or ehrlichial colitis)
detail:
• Infective organism is Ehrlichia risticii spread by flukes, ticks, helminths, and aquatic insects
• Signs include depression, anorexia, pyrexia, decreased gut sounds, abdominal pain, watery diarrhea
• Isolation necessary
• Treated w oxytetracycline, fluids (balanced electrolytic solution)
• Vaccines have high rate of effectiveness

title: Hyperkalemic periodic paralysis (Horses)
detail:
• Results from a genetic mutation
• Signs include muscle fasciculations, colic, sweating, respiratory distress, prolapsed nictitating membrane (third eyelid), loose feces, ataxia
• Low potassium diet and fresh water is important for horses w HYPP, stress should be minimized, and they should not be ridden due to gait problems

title: Strangles (Horses)
detail:
• Caused by the bacteria Streptococcus equi equi
• Leads to breathing and swallowing (dysphagia) issues, low survival rate
• Highly contagious, requires isolation; spread through direct contact or shared items, anywhere a draining abscess has touched
• Some horses are only carriers
• Abscesses on lymph nodes will develop into empyema abscesses (pus-filled lesions), which hot packs or lancing can help drain
• Feed slurries if dysphagia occurs
• No cure, but constant fresh water access, warmth, antipyretics, antibiotics help symptoms
• An intranasal vaccine reduces seriousness of symptoms

title: Equine herpesvirus 1 (EHV-1)
detail:
• Infects the respiratory tract, lymph nodes, and endothelial tissue in the nose, lungs, adrenal glands, thyroid, and CNS
• Signs include fever, depression, inappetence, nasal discharge, cough, along with possible neurological signs (ungainly movement, incontinence, posterior ataxia, absence of tail tone, sitting like a dog or recumbency due to hind leg paralysis)
• Vaccines during pregnancy available (months 5-7-9)
• Treated w antibiotics, anti-inflammatory drugs, or corticosteroids

title: Equine herpesvirus 4 (EHV-4)
detail:
• Causes rhinopnemonitis, effects on the respiratory tract and lymph glands (no neurological and pregnancy issues like EHV-1)
• Spread through close contact or aerosolized body fluids
• Signs include upper respiratory symptoms like wheezing, rhonchi, rales, stridor, as well as swelling of lymph nodes
• Isolation recommended, should avoid stress and cold
• Post-infection vaccine reduces symptoms

title: Equine infectious anemia (swamp fever)
detail:
• Spread by blood-feeding insects; all body fluids and tissues of infective animals are infectious
• Iatrogenic spread via needles and medical supplies common
• Can penetrate placental barrier
• Infection is for life with recurring remission and exacerbation
• Signs include fever, depression, weight loss, anorexia, anemia
• No cure—infected animals are usually euthanized, or totally isolated (even from insects) for life

title: Laminitis (Horses)
detail:
• Irritation and inflammation of the epidermal (insensitive) and dermal (sensitive) laminae, which are the layers that hold the distal phalanx within the hoof wall; most common in front feet
• Can cause irregular gait, severe lameness, detachment of hoof wall
• Can result from high fever, endotoxemia, sepsis, equine metabolic syndrome (from grain overconsumption or sudden exposure to lush pasture), road founder (trauma to feet)
• Signs include lameness, depression, lethargy, apprehension, pyrexia, anorexia, hoof sensitivity, increased digital pulse and temperature
• Radiographs detect extent
• Treated w anti-inflammatory drugs, acepromazine, fluids like LRS, trimming hoof

title: Navicular disease (Horses)
detail:
• Chronic, degenerative; produces lameness and deterioration of the navicular bone (a small bone in the foot)
• May present w stumbling, shorter strides, intermittent lameness, hoof pain
• Flexion tests, nerve blocking, and radiograph confirm diagnosis
• Treated w anti-inflammatory drugs, vasodilators, corrective hoof trimming and shoeing, and if all else fails surgical neurectomy (nerve cut above the fetlock)

title: White muscle disease (Cattle)
detail:
• Aka nutritional myodegeneration
• Occurs in young calves, lambs, and kids born to dams receiving diets deficient in selenium during gestation
• Deficiency of selenium or vitamin E may cause degeneration of cardiac or skeletal muscle
• If skeletal muscles are affected, muscular weakness or stiffness followed by eventual recumbency and death may occur
